ygData.subject: Re: Problem with 64 bit installation
ygData.msgSnippet: Hi Harry, I am continuing my attempt to compile cantera for 64bit suse 10.2. I am using last cvs (two days ago). I found that I need to use lapack and blas

Hi Harry,
I am continuing my attempt to compile cantera for 64bit suse 10.2=
.
I am using last cvs (two days ago). I found that I need to use lapack
and=
 blas from suse 10.2 64 bit rpm. I recompiled also sundials with
-fPIC flag=
. It allowed me to continue father in compilation but after
it I again met =
the following error:

g++ -pthread -shared build/temp.linux-x86_64-2.5/src/=
pycantera.o
-L/home/sergey/src/cantera/build/lib/x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu
-=
L/usr/lib64 -L/home/sergey/sundials/lib -L/usr/lib/python2.5/config
-lclib =
-lzeroD -loneD -ltransport -lcantera -lconverters -lcaThermo
-llapack -lbla=
s -lsundials_cvodes -lsundials_nvecserial -lctmath -ltpx
-lctf2c -lctf2c -l=
m -lpython2.5 -o
build/lib.linux-x86_64-2.5/Cantera/_cantera.so
/usr/lib64/=
gcc/x86_64-suse-linux/4.1.2/../../../../x86_64-suse-linux/bin/ld:
/home/ser=
gey/src/cantera/build/lib/x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu/libctmath.a(dpcoef.o):
r=
elocation R_X86_64_32 against `a local symbol' can not be used when
making =
a shared object; recompile with -fPIC
/home/sergey/src/cantera/build/lib/x8=
6_64-unknown-linux-gnu/libctmath.a:
could not read symbols: Bad value
colle=
ct2: ld returned 1 exit status
setup.py:96: DeprecationWarning: raising a s=
tring exception is deprecated
  raise 'Error encountered while building or =
installing the Cantera
python modules!'
Traceback (most recent call last):
=
  File "setup.py", line 96, in <module>
    raise 'Error encountered while =
building or installing the Cantera
python modules!'
Error encountered while=
 building or installing the Cantera python modules!
make[1]: *** [_build] E=
rror 1
make[1]: Leaving directory `/home/sergey/src/cantera/Cantera/python'=

make: *** [python] Error 2

Probably libctmath also must be compiled with =
-fPIC, but how can I do it?

Thank you for your help.
Sergey







--- In =
cantera@yahoogroups.com, "Moffat, Harry K" <hkmoffa@...> wrote:
>
> Hi Serg=
ey,
> 
>   Yes, indeed it appears to be another bug, which only happens on =
a 64
> bit compile using the full python option, at least on my version of
=
> linux. Apparently, the compiler is now insisting (or perhaps has always
>=
 insisted but somehow we got away with it before) that all code being
> lin=
ked into a shared library be compiled either all with or all without
> the =
-fPIC option. The bug below is due to inconsistent compilations of
> differ=
ent parts of cantera.
> 
> After fixing this issue manually, by adding -fPI=
C to various ext library
> Makefiles, I was able to compile cantera.so_, ma=
ke the entire cantera
> package, and install it. It then passed the full te=
st suite.
> 
> Note, however, that to do this for the full python option, I=
 had to use
> a 64 bit version of python, that I compiled myself, as the de=
fault
> python shipped with my linux os is 32 bit, and therefore would not =
work
> with 64 bit cantera shared libraries. The minimal python option does=
n't
> involve this complexity, because it doesn't use compiled C++ code.
> =

> I'll work on modifying the Makefiles, to ensure that a uniform treatment=

> of the -fPIC option is insisted upon, later today.
> 
> Thanks again Ser=
gey for pointing this bug out.
> 
> Best wishes,
> Harry
> 
>

at                                             (w) (505)

ot be used when
